text.Prompt:
Smart meters

Although BlackBerry once held and then lost the smartphone crown, the company still excels at mobile device management services. And it plans to build upon that strength by applying it to the growing market of non-traditional connected devices in the Internet of Things (IoT) market.

The company announced a managed certificate service through its subsidiary Certicom on Tuesday to help secure a wide range of IoT devices. BlackBerry says that it already began issuing certificates through Certicom for a smart parking meter project in the UK; a region with more than 104 million such meters and home energy management devices.

Over the past seven years, Certicom has previously issued 60 million such certficates for devices like these that use the ZigBee Smart Energy specification, notes BlackBerry. The certificates help secure the data captured by the smart meters and energy management systems, using what Certicom calls Elliptic Curve Cryptography. Certicom notes that the managed certificate service was designed to scale up for supporting hundreds of millions of devices.

That's a key aspect, given that more and more everyday devices are gaining some type of connectivity. While there are roughly 2 billion smartphones in use today, the potential figure for other devices with some type of wireless radio for providing or collecting data is staggering. A Gartner forecast from November of 2014, for example, pegged the figure at 25 billion connected devices by 2020.

BlackBerry surely isn't the only company that wants to secure these devices, but it's smart to start building the effort now.

Mobile security is still a core competency for the company and regardless of how it's doing in the smartphone business, BlackBerry is still a trusted brand by many for its secure services and device management. It has to capitalize on that early in the IoT market before it faces a repeat of what happened in the smartphone market: An upstart that upends a core of BlackBerry's business.

The service is already being used for the smart parking meter project in the UK, where Certicom has issued certificates for more than 104 million meters. Over the past seven years, Certicom has issued 60 million certificates for devices that use the ZigBee Smart Energy specification. The certificates help secure the data captured by the smart meters and energy management systems, using Elliptic Curve Cryptography. The managed certificate service has been designed to scale up for supporting hundreds of millions of devices.
text.Response B: Blackerry has launched a managed certificate service, which is designed to secure the Internet of Things. The certificate is part of the company's certification service division, Certicom, and is said to be designed to secure devices such as smart meters. The company has already begun issuing certificates through Certicom for a smart parking meter project in the UK. text.Prompt:
Given the document below, determine if the summary is factually consistent with the document. 
Document: A Romanian court on Tuesday agreed to extend former kickboxer and social media influencer Andrew Tate's detention on suspicion of human trafficking, rape, and forming an organized crime group for another 30 days, according to reports.

Tate was arrested on Dec. 29. 2022, with his brother Tristan and two Romanian women after Romanian authorities raided their Bucharest properties and held them for 24 hours.

As of Tuesday, none of the four detainees has been formally charged.

ANDREW TATE DETAINED IN ROMANIA ON SUSPICION OF HUMAN TRAFFICKING: REPORTS

The Associated Press reported that a spokesperson from Romania's anti-organized crime agency DIICOT, Romona Bolla, said a request by the prosecutor to continue to hold the Tates for 30 more days was approved by the Bucharest Tribunal. The two Romanian women are to be placed on house arrest.

Tuesday's extension was the third one granted since the Tates were arrested at the end of 2022.

On Jan. 20, a judge ordered to keep the Tates behind bars as an investigation into their affairs continued.

The AP reported that the judge considered the "particular dangerousness of the defendants" and their capacity to identify victims "with an increased vulnerability, in search of better life opportunities," when deciding to hold the brothers behind bars.

ANDREW TATE CLAIMS BIG TECH BANNED HIM AFTER 'LARGE SWATHS' OF PEOPLE AGREED WITH HIS 'MASCULINE VALUES'

The Tates appealed the judge's decision but lost on Feb. 1.

An attorney representing the brothers, Eugen Vidineac, reportedly told reporters before the hearing on Tuesday that the defense would challenge an extension, insisting there was not enough evidence to keep his clients in custody.

Andrew Tate also turned to Twitter before the decision.

"I can easily think myself into euphoric gratefulness for things as simple as having air to breathe," he said. "I can easily think myself into the deepest and darkest depression. I've seen hell. I've lived hell. I can produce either state. Your reality is self-constructed."

CONSERVATIVE NONPROFIT LAUNCHES AD CAMPAIGN TARGETING BILLS OVER BIG TECH CENSORSHIP

Shortly after the judge extended the Tate brothers' detention, Andrew posted again.

"I will meditate deeply over this decision," he tweeted.

Tate and his three alleged partners had reportedly been under a criminal investigation since April after they were suspected of being involved in a human trafficking scheme in which at least six women were sexually exploited.

"The four suspects...appear to have created an organized crime group with the purpose of recruiting, housing and exploiting women by forcing them to create pornographic content meant to be seen on specialized websites for a cost," prosecutors said. "They would have gained important sums of money."

CLICK HERE TO DOWNLOAD THE FOX NEWS APP

Reports on Friday suggested that Tate's renewed social media presence on Twitter may have led to his own arrest.

The Associated Press contributed to this report.

The summary is not consistent with the document because the former kickboxer and social media influencer Andrew Tate was arrested on Dec. 29. 2022 and has been in detention since that day, as of Tuesday, none of the four detained individuals has been formally charged.
Therefore, the answer is No.

The document reports that Andrew Tate and his brother were ordered to spend another 30 days in detention as investigators look into accusations against them. Therefore, the summary accurately reflects the contents of the document.

text.Prompt:
Smart meters

Although BlackBerry once held and then lost the smartphone crown, the company still excels at mobile device management services. And it plans to build upon that strength by applying it to the growing market of non-traditional connected devices in the Internet of Things (IoT) market.

The company announced a managed certificate service through its subsidiary Certicom on Tuesday to help secure a wide range of IoT devices. BlackBerry says that it already began issuing certificates through Certicom for a smart parking meter project in the UK; a region with more than 104 million such meters and home energy management devices.

Over the past seven years, Certicom has previously issued 60 million such certficates for devices like these that use the ZigBee Smart Energy specification, notes BlackBerry. The certificates help secure the data captured by the smart meters and energy management systems, using what Certicom calls Elliptic Curve Cryptography. Certicom notes that the managed certificate service was designed to scale up for supporting hundreds of millions of devices.

That's a key aspect, given that more and more everyday devices are gaining some type of connectivity. While there are roughly 2 billion smartphones in use today, the potential figure for other devices with some type of wireless radio for providing or collecting data is staggering. A Gartner forecast from November of 2014, for example, pegged the figure at 25 billion connected devices by 2020.

BlackBerry surely isn't the only company that wants to secure these devices, but it's smart to start building the effort now.

Mobile security is still a core competency for the company and regardless of how it's doing in the smartphone business, BlackBerry is still a trusted brand by many for its secure services and device management. It has to capitalize on that early in the IoT market before it faces a repeat of what happened in the smartphone market: An upstart that upends a core of BlackBerry's business.

Document: A Romanian court on Tuesday agreed to extend former kickboxer and social media influencer Andrew Tate's detention on suspicion of human trafficking, rape, and forming an organized crime group for another 30 days, according to reports.

Tate was arrested on Dec. 29. 2022, with his brother Tristan and two Romanian women after Romanian authorities raided their Bucharest properties and held them for 24 hours.

As of Tuesday, none of the four detainees has been formally charged.

ANDREW TATE DETAINED IN ROMANIA ON SUSPICION OF HUMAN TRAFFICKING: REPORTS

The Associated Press reported that a spokesperson from Romania's anti-organized crime agency DIICOT, Romona Bolla, said a request by the prosecutor to continue to hold the Tates for 30 more days was approved by the Bucharest Tribunal. The two Romanian women are to be placed on house arrest.

Tuesday's extension was the third one granted since the Tates were arrested at the end of 2022.

On Jan. 20, a judge ordered to keep the Tates behind bars as an investigation into their affairs continued.

The AP reported that the judge considered the "particular dangerousness of the defendants" and their capacity to identify victims "with an increased vulnerability, in search of better life opportunities," when deciding to hold the brothers behind bars.

ANDREW TATE CLAIMS BIG TECH BANNED HIM AFTER 'LARGE SWATHS' OF PEOPLE AGREED WITH HIS 'MASCULINE VALUES'

The Tates appealed the judge's decision but lost on Feb. 1.

An attorney representing the brothers, Eugen Vidineac, reportedly told reporters before the hearing on Tuesday that the defense would challenge an extension, insisting there was not enough evidence to keep his clients in custody.

Andrew Tate also turned to Twitter before the decision.

"I can easily think myself into euphoric gratefulness for things as simple as having air to breathe," he said. "I can easily think myself into the deepest and darkest depression. I've seen hell. I've lived hell. I can produce either state. Your reality is self-constructed."

CONSERVATIVE NONPROFIT LAUNCHES AD CAMPAIGN TARGETING BILLS OVER BIG TECH CENSORSHIP

Shortly after the judge extended the Tate brothers' detention, Andrew posted again.

"I will meditate deeply over this decision," he tweeted.

Tate and his three alleged partners had reportedly been under a criminal investigation since April after they were suspected of being involved in a human trafficking scheme in which at least six women were sexually exploited.

"The four suspects...appear to have created an organized crime group with the purpose of recruiting, housing and exploiting women by forcing them to create pornographic content meant to be seen on specialized websites for a cost," prosecutors said. "They would have gained important sums of money."

CLICK HERE TO DOWNLOAD THE FOX NEWS APP

Reports on Friday suggested that Tate's renewed social media presence on Twitter may have led to his own arrest.

The Associated Press contributed to this report.

text.Response A: The summary is factually consistent with the document. The document reports that Andrew Tate and his brother were ordered to spend another 30 days in detention as investigators look into accusations against them. The summary also reports that Andrew Tate was ordered to spend another 30 days in detention, and that his brother was also detained. Therefore, the summary accurately reflects the contents of the document.
text.Response B: Yes

As of Tuesday, none of the four detainees has been formally charged.

ANDREW TATE DETAINED IN ROMANIA ON SUSPICION OF HUMAN TRAFFICKING: REPORTS

The Associated Press reported that a spokesperson from Romania's anti-organized crime agency DIICOT, Romona Bolla, said a request by the prosecutor to continue to hold the Tates for 30 more days was approved by the Bucharest Tribunal. The two Romanian women are to be placed on house arrest.

Tuesday's extension was the third one granted since the Tates were arrested at the end of 2022.

On Jan. 20, a judge ordered to keep the Tates behind bars as an investigation into their affairs continued.

The AP reported that the judge considered the "particular dangerousness of the defendants" and their capacity to identify victims "with an increased vulnerability, in search of better life opportunities," when deciding to hold the brothers behind bars.

ANDREW TATE CLAIMS BIG TECH BANNED HIM AFTER 'LARGE SWATHS' OF PEOPLE AGREED WITH HIS 'MASCULINE VALUES'

The Tates appealed the judge's decision but lost on Feb. 1.

An attorney representing the brothers, Eugen Vidineac, reportedly told reporters before the hearing on Tuesday that the defense would challenge an extension, insisting there was not enough evidence to keep his clients in custody.

Andrew Tate also turned to Twitter before the decision.

"I can easily think myself into euphoric gratefulness for things as simple as having air to breathe," he said. "I can easily think myself into the deepest and darkest depression. I've seen hell. I've lived hell. I can produce either state. Your reality is self-constructed."

CONSERVATIVE NONPROFIT LAUNCHES AD CAMPAIGN TARGETING BILLS OVER BIG TECH CENSORSHIP

Shortly after the judge extended the Tate brothers' detention, Andrew posted again.

"I will meditate deeply over this decision," he tweeted.

Tate and his three alleged partners had reportedly been under a criminal investigation since April after they were suspected of being involved in a human trafficking scheme in which at least six women were sexually exploited.

"The four suspects...appear to have created an organized crime group with the purpose of recruiting, housing and exploiting women by forcing them to create pornographic content meant to be seen on specialized websites for a cost," prosecutors said. "They would have gained important sums of money."

text.Prompt:
Smart meters

Although BlackBerry once held and then lost the smartphone crown, the company still excels at mobile device management services. And it plans to build upon that strength by applying it to the growing market of non-traditional connected devices in the Internet of Things (IoT) market.

The company announced a managed certificate service through its subsidiary Certicom on Tuesday to help secure a wide range of IoT devices. BlackBerry says that it already began issuing certificates through Certicom for a smart parking meter project in the UK; a region with more than 104 million such meters and home energy management devices.

Over the past seven years, Certicom has previously issued 60 million such certficates for devices like these that use the ZigBee Smart Energy specification, notes BlackBerry. The certificates help secure the data captured by the smart meters and energy management systems, using what Certicom calls Elliptic Curve Cryptography. Certicom notes that the managed certificate service was designed to scale up for supporting hundreds of millions of devices.

That's a key aspect, given that more and more everyday devices are gaining some type of connectivity. While there are roughly 2 billion smartphones in use today, the potential figure for other devices with some type of wireless radio for providing or collecting data is staggering. A Gartner forecast from November of 2014, for example, pegged the figure at 25 billion connected devices by 2020.

BlackBerry surely isn't the only company that wants to secure these devices, but it's smart to start building the effort now.

Mobile security is still a core competency for the company and regardless of how it's doing in the smartphone business, BlackBerry is still a trusted brand by many for its secure services and device management. It has to capitalize on that early in the IoT market before it faces a repeat of what happened in the smartphone market: An upstart that upends a core of BlackBerry's business.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: US-based delivery company Fetchr has joined a partnership that is developing the first aerial drone home delivery service in the United Arab Emirates. The partnership between UAE-based technology firm Eniverse and US company Skycart had earlier announced that was planning to bring Space Autonomous Drones to specific areas of Dubai. California-based Skycart already offers a similar service to its users, which delivers packages to their doorstep. Fetchr's founder, Idriss Al Rifai, said his company's involvement in the drone project will help take it "the last mile".
text.Response B: Blackberry plans to use it expertise in mobile device management service to expand into the growing market of non-traditional connected devices in the Internet of Things (IoT) market. It has announced a managed certificate service through its subsidiary Certicom to help secure a wide range of IoT devices, and has already begun issuing certificates for a smart parking meter project in the UK.

Document: A Romanian court on Tuesday agreed to extend former kickboxer and social media influencer Andrew Tate's detention on suspicion of human trafficking, rape, and forming an organized crime group for another 30 days, according to reports.

Tate was arrested on Dec. 29. 2022, with his brother Tristan and two Romanian women after Romanian authorities raided their Bucharest properties and held them for 24 hours.

As of Tuesday, none of the four detainees has been formally charged.

ANDREW TATE DETAINED IN ROMANIA ON SUSPICION OF HUMAN TRAFFICKING: REPORTS

The Associated Press reported that a spokesperson from Romania's anti-organized crime agency DIICOT, Romona Bolla, said a request by the prosecutor to continue to hold the Tates for 30 more days was approved by the Bucharest Tribunal. The two Romanian women are to be placed on house arrest.

Tuesday's extension was the third one granted since the Tates were arrested at the end of 2022.

On Jan. 20, a judge ordered to keep the Tates behind bars as an investigation into their affairs continued.

The AP reported that the judge considered the "particular dangerousness of the defendants" and their capacity to identify victims "with an increased vulnerability, in search of better life opportunities," when deciding to hold the brothers behind bars.

ANDREW TATE CLAIMS BIG TECH BANNED HIM AFTER 'LARGE SWATHS' OF PEOPLE AGREED WITH HIS 'MASCULINE VALUES'

The Tates appealed the judge's decision but lost on Feb. 1.

An attorney representing the brothers, Eugen Vidineac, reportedly told reporters before the hearing on Tuesday that the defense would challenge an extension, insisting there was not enough evidence to keep his clients in custody.

Andrew Tate also turned to Twitter before the decision.

"I can easily think myself into euphoric gratefulness for things as simple as having air to breathe," he said. "I can easily think myself into the deepest and darkest depression. I've seen hell. I've lived hell. I can produce either state. Your reality is self-constructed."

CONSERVATIVE NONPROFIT LAUNCHES AD CAMPAIGN TARGETING BILLS OVER BIG TECH CENSORSHIP

Shortly after the judge extended the Tate brothers' detention, Andrew posted again.

"I will meditate deeply over this decision," he tweeted.

Tate and his three alleged partners had reportedly been under a criminal investigation since April after they were suspected of being involved in a human trafficking scheme in which at least six women were sexually exploited.

"The four suspects...appear to have created an organized crime group with the purpose of recruiting, housing and exploiting women by forcing them to create pornographic content meant to be seen on specialized websites for a cost," prosecutors said. "They would have gained important sums of money."

CLICK HERE TO DOWNLOAD THE FOX NEWS APP

Reports on Friday suggested that Tate's renewed social media presence on Twitter may have led to his own arrest.

The Associated Press contributed to this report.

"The four suspects...appear to have created an organized crime group with the purpose of recruiting, housing and exploiting women by forcing them to create pornographic content meant to be seen on specialized websites for a cost," prosecutors said. "They would have gained important sums of money."
